name: Charmeleon

attacks.name: Flamethrower
attacks.text: Discard 1 Fire Energy card attached to Charmeleon in order to use this attack.

flavorText: When it swings its burning tail, it raises the temperature to unbearably high levels.

strengths: Slash uses any energy type, making it flexible in multi-type decks
50 damage from Flamethrower is solid for a Stage 1 Pokémon
80 HP is decent survivability for a mid-evolution
Only 1 retreat cost makes it easy to switch out
Can attack while building energy for Charizard evolution
Doesn't require specific Fire energy for Slash attack
Evolves into one of the most powerful cards in the set
weaknesses: Generally seen as just a stepping stone to Charizard
Water weakness makes it vulnerable to common threats
Flamethrower's energy discard slows down Charizard setup
Lower HP than other Stage 1 attackers like Arcanine
Overshadowed by Charizard in most deck strategies
30 damage from Slash is underwhelming compared to other options
counters: Blastoise - Water weakness and Rain Dance make this a terrible matchup
Staryu/Starmie - Fast Water attackers that exploit weakness
Energy Removal - Prevents reaching attack thresholds
Gust of Wind - Forces Charmeleon out before it can evolve
Professor Oak - Opponent may discard your Charizard from hand

description: Charmeleon is the Stage 1 evolution of Charmander and the crucial stepping stone to the powerful Charizard. With 80 HP and versatile attacking options, Charmeleon can serve as both a transitional evolution and a functional mid-game attacker. Its low retreat cost and flexible energy requirements make it an important component in Fire-type evolution strategies.
competitiveHistory: Charmeleon's role in competitive play was almost entirely as a necessary evolution step to Charizard. While it could function as an attacker in casual play, competitive decks often used Pokémon Breeder to skip it entirely. When it did see play, it was usually attacking out of necessity rather than by design. Its presence in tournament decks was ubiquitous in Charizard builds, but it was rarely the intended active Pokémon.

rulings.ruling: Slash requires 3 Colorless energy, which can be paid with any combination of energy types, including all Fire Energy.
You choose which Fire Energy card to discard from Charmeleon when using Flamethrower.
You can only evolve a Pokémon once per turn, and you cannot evolve a Pokémon on the same turn it was played or evolved (except with Pokémon Breeder).
Pokémon Breeder allows you to put Charizard directly onto Charmander, bypassing Charmeleon entirely.
